p: Essential oils are composed of a complex mixture of compounds which give a characteristic odour and flavour to the plants [ 1]. The compounds are grouped into main compounds (20–95%), secondary compounds (1–20%), and trace compounds with less than 1% concentration [ 8]. The flavour and aroma of plants are influenced by the type and amount of compounds present in the essential oil [ 9, 10]. Oxygenated monoterpenes are the major contributor to the taste and aroma of essential oils [ 11]. Essential oils from plants such as lemon grass have been used for a long time in aromatherapy and medicinal applications [ 4]. There are other compounds that bring about variation in the colour of essential oils from different plants [ 4]. Most essential oils contain natural monoterpenes and sequiterpenes, with a variety of functional groups that contribute to antifungal and antibacterial properties [ 12].
